results.name: Number of 1-digits in primorial base expansion of n.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..32768
Index entries for sequences related to primorial base
formula: For n >= 1, a(A143293(n-1)) = n. [This is the first occurrence of each n]
example: In primorial base (A049345), 87 is written as "2411" because 87 = 2*A002110(3) + 4*A002110(2) + 1*A002110(1) + 1*A002110(0) = 2*30 + 4*6 + 1*2 + 1*1. Only two of these digits are "1"'s, thus a(87) = 2.
program: (PARI) A328614(n) = { my(s=0, p=2); while(n, s += (1==(n%p)); n = n\p; p = nextprime(1+p)); (s); };
xref: Cf. A143293 (positions of records after initial zero).
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Oct 22 2019
